fields.Title of Presentation: Mucosal Vaccination Induces Systemic Humoral Reponses to West Nile Virus Domain III
fields.Description/Abstract: West Nile virus (WNV) causes serious neuroinvasive disease and remains endemic in many parts of the world. Despite advances in our understanding of WNV pathogenesis, there exists a significant need for a human vaccine.  The domain III (DIII) region of the WNV envelope protein contains epitopes that are the target of neutralizing antibodies.  We have constructed a chimeric fusion of the non-toxic CTA2/B domains of cholera toxin (CT) to DIII for investigation as a novel mucosal WNV vaccine.  The DIII-CTA2/B chimera and DIII alone were purified from E. coli. Assembly of the chimera and cholera toxin receptor-binding were verified by SDS-PAGE, western blot, GM1 ELISA, and confocal microscopy. Groups of BALB/c mice were immunized intranasally with DIII-CTA2/B, DIII alone, DIII mixed with CTA2/B, or CTA2/B control, and boosted at 10 days. Analysis of serum IgG showed that mucosal immunization with DIII-CTA2/B and DIII antigen alone induced significant DIII-specific humoral immunity and drove isotype switching to IgG2a.  Secretory IgA from nasal washes confirmed the induction of a mucosal response. Functional bactericidal assays revealed that immunized mice produce anti-DIII antibodies that trigger complement-mediated killing. Our results indicate that the DIII-CTA2/B chimera, and to a lesser extent DIII alone, are immunogenic after mucosal delivery, and merit further investigation as novel WNV vaccine candidates.
